Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Theoretical and Experimental Investigations of Inter-Molecular forces Between Environmental Pollutants and Carbon nanotubes
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this collaborative award, the Environmental Chemical Sciences Program of the Division of Chemistry is funding Professor Mesfin Tsige of the University of Akron and Professors Xingmao Ma and Saikat Talapatra of Southern Illinois University at Carbondale to explore solutions for removing some of the most prevalent contaminants from water using carbon-based nanomaterials. Escalating environmental pollution problems, such as contamination of water with hazardous chemicals, and the need for proper restoration of clean environment, is a global/societal concern that warrants immediate attention. This project endeavors to help elucidate the underlying mechanisms for the interactions between carbon nanotubes (CNTs) and organic contaminants, which is a major step forward in developing CNT-based environmental remediation method. The project provides training to undergraduate and graduate students in nanofabrication, characterization and computational techniques and their applications for contamination removal from water. The collaborative research team is also organizing an international workshop at Addis Ababa University, Ethiopia, in order to raise the global awareness of emerging water contamination issues.

Specifically, state of the art experimental tools as well as advanced modeling are utilized to understand how different chemical contaminants interact with different architectures of CNTs, in order to identify the most suitable carbon nanotube based materials to remove hazardous chemicals from water efficiently. The project studies (i) the nature of the adsorption for organic contaminants (in particular, the ionizable compounds) with varying molecular structures and properties, (ii) the extent to which the presence of co-contaminants as well as key environmental parameters affect the adsorption behavior of organic contaminants, and (iii) the adsorption kinetics for CNTs with different sizes or curvature and surface chemistry. The research team plans to perform systematic adsorption studies of a wide array of organic contaminants on CNTs and conduct extensive electronic structure calculations and molecular dynamics simulations to gain insights on the intermolecular forces taking place at the liquid-solid interface when contaminants are exposed to CNTs in water. The collabortive team also plans to investigate how environmental conditions such as ionic strength and pH shift the intermolecular forces and affect the adsorption behavior of organic contaminants onto CNTs. Built on the understanding of the intermolecular forces, it should be possible to examine how different surface functionalization approaches affect the adsorption behavior of organic contaminants to CNTs, setting out defining principles for the design of functional adsorbant nanoparticles.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A large quantity of emerging contaminants including pharmaceuticals, personal care products, flame retardants, disinfection by-products possess oxygen-containing functional groups and can dissociate at certain environmental conditions. The ionized compounds are usually negatively charged, display much higher solubility than their neutral counterparts, and are expected to demonstrate much lower adsorption capacity on a variety of environmental surfaces based on the calculated pH-dependent octanol water partitioning coefficient. Surprisingly, many ionized compounds displayed much stronger adsorption to several carbonaceous materials containing carboxyl or hydroxyl functional groups than expected. Unique intermolecular forces such as the charge-assisted hydrogen bonding (-)CAHB was ascribed as one of the very strong intermolecular forces, leading to much stronger adsorption of ionized compounds on functionalized carbonaceous materials. However, despite the exciting progresses in previous studies, understanding is still lacking with regard to how the molecular size or structure of ionized compounds affect their capability to form such strong intermolecular forces, and how significnat are these strong intermolecular forces for emerging contaminants with more complex structures than most probe molecules used in the literature before. Using a variety of aromatic carboxylic acids and commercial multi-walled carbon nanotubes, and house-made single-walled carbon nanotubes, the PIs probed experimentally the adsorption capacity and affinity of these compounds on carbon nanotubes at different environmental conditions (e.g. different pH values).  By combining our experimental studies with advanced molecular simulation, significant new insights into the adsorption mechanisms of ionizable compounds on carbon nanotubes were obtained. We noticed that hydrophobic effect and electrostatic interactions are two predominant mechanisms for the adsorption of ionizable compounds on graphitized carbon nanotubes. However, for carbon nanotubes with oxygen-containing functional groups, strong molecular forces such as charged assisted hydrogen bonding ((-)CAHB) can be formed, but the forces are substantially weaker for compounds with large molecular size (e.g. more benzene rings in the structure) and compounds with additional functional groups next to the carboxylic acid functional group. Steric hindrance and altered approaching orientation of ionized compounds with more complex structures are considered two main reasons for their lower adsorption on carbon nanotubes. We also found that the adsorption of these compounds on house-made single-walled carbon nanotubes are much higher than multi-walled carbon nanotubes, despite the fact that the specific surface area of the single-walled carbon nanotubes is much smaller. The finding highlighted that other factors in addition to the specific surface area govern the adsorption of ionizable compounds on carbon nanotubes. Our collaborative efforts between experimental measurement and molecular simulation suggest that the bundling of single-walled carbon nanotubes generate many high energy adsorption sites, which explains the unusually high adsorption capacity of ionizable compounds on single-walled carbon nanotubes. In summary, the project generated significant mechanistic insights into the adsorption behavior of ionizable compounds on carbon nanotube surfaces, shedding more light on the investigation on the fate and transport of emerging contaminants in the environment.
